titleInfo.title: Causal Investigation of Visual Cortical Disinhibition in Fear Memory

mods:mods.abstract: Fear and anxiety disorders remain difficult to treat, but research into the mechanisms underlying fear memory would provide an important insight into their underlying pathology and identify effective targets for future therapeutics. The sensory cortex has traditionally been overshadowed by the well-documented roles of the amygdala and the prefrontal cortex in fear and anxiety. However, growing evidence in the past decade suggests that it would be a critical player in fear processing (particularly, long-term fear memory) and thus an accessible and effective target for mitigating pathological fear. The current study aims to causally elucidate the role of the human visual cortex in underlying fear memory. Specifically, we tested the hypothesis that conditioning-induced disinhibition in the human visual cortex is critical for the formation of fear memory. In a Pavlovian fear conditioning study, we combined experimental augmentation of alpha oscillations (8-12 Hz; critical for cortical inhibition) via high-definition alpha-frequency transcranial alternating current stimulation (HD α-tACS) with simultaneous EEG-fMRI before, during, and immediately after conditioning, as well as EEG recordings on Day 2 and Day 8. As the alpha oscillation acts as a key inhibitory modulator of visual cortical activity, alpha augmentation via α-tACS would experimentally enhance visual cortical inhibition, thereby resisting disinhibition evoked by fear conditioning and impeding fear memory formation. Indeed, we demonstrated that α-tACS (vs. sham control) prevented such suppression during fear memory consolidation (as indexed by EEG on Day 1). Importantly, we found that during fear memory recall (on Day 8), α-tACS (vs. sham control) diminished visual cortical response (as indexed by the visual evoked potential—P1) to the CS+ (vs. CS-). Moreover, relative to the Sham Group, α-tACS weakened activation of the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and the right early visual cortex during immediate recall testing. These results causally evinced the critical role of sensory cortex in human fear memory, highlighting a novel mechanism—sensory cortical disinhibition—in this process. The findings thus expand canonical fear models centered on the amygdala and prefrontal cortex. Importantly, by demonstrating the efficacy of α-tACS in disrupting fear memory, the study further promotes novel therapeutics for fear and anxiety disorders via non-invasive brain stimulation.
